div.l: And yet haue y alwey a coltis toth
As many a yeer as it is passed henne
Sen þat my tappe of lyf began to renne
For sikirli whanne I was born anone
Deth drew the tappe of life ⁊and leet it gon̄
And ever seth hath so þe tappe I ronne
Til þat almost al empty is the tonne
The streme of lif now droppith on þe chimbe
The seli tunge may wel ringe ⁊and chimbe
Of wrecchidnesse þat past is ful yore
With olde folk saue dotage þer is nomore
Whanne þat our͗e ost had herd þis sermonyng
He gan to speken as lordli as a kyng
And saide what amountith al þis wit
What shul we speke alday of holi writ
Þe devel made a reve forto preche
Or of a sowter a shipman or a leche
Say forth þi tale and tari not þe tyme
Lo depford it is half wey to pryme
Lo grenewich þat many a shrewe is ynne
It were al tyme thi tale forto begynne
Now seris quod Oswold þe Reve
I pray you alle þat ye yow not greve
Þouȝ þat y answere ⁊and somedel sette hi soun̄
For leful is with fors forto sown̄
This dronkyn myllere hath y told vs here
How þat begilid was a maister carpentere
ꝐParauenture in scorn̄ for I am on
And be your leve I shal him quite Anon̄
Riȝt in his chorlis termys wol I speke
I pray to god his necke mowe to breke
He can wel in myn ye se a stalk
But in his owen he can not se a balk
The ende of the Revys Prolog
begynnyng his tale
¶ ReveAt trompynton not fer fro Cambrig
Ther goth a brook ⁊and ouer þat a brig
Vpon the which brook þer stondith a mylle
And this is verri soth þat I you telle
